chunks: One of the bigger monthly expenses outside of rent in Lisbon is the food bill. Lisbon has a variety of options in terms of groceries and restaurants. The food budget in Lisbon will vary depending on where you go. Groceries in Lisbon typically cost between €250 and €400 per month. Shopping in places like Aldi, Continente or Lidl will help keep the grocery budget down.

The streets in Lisbon aren't very car-friendly. The best way to get around Lisbon is by using the public transportation system. A monthly subscription for public transport in Lisbon can be purchased with a Navegante card. The price of a public transport subscription in Lisbon depends on the area you live. The municipal subscription for public transport in Lisbon costs €30 per month. The municipal subscription covers travel around Lisbon, Amadora, and Odivelas. The metropolitan subscription for public transport in Lisbon costs €40 per month. The metropolitan subscription covers travel around the Lisbon metropolitan area. A pay-as-you-go subscription for public transport in Lisbon can be purchased. Each journey with a pay-as-you-go subscription costs €1.61. Taxis in Lisbon have a base rate of €3.25. Taxis in Lisbon charge an extra €0.47 per km. Scooter or bike rentals in Lisbon usually cost less than €5 per journey.

The cost of rent is the biggest living expense in Lisbon. The average cost of rent in Lisbon peaked during 2023. The average cost of rent in Lisbon has been decreasing since 2023. The rent cost in Lisbon varies depending on the neighbourhood and type of accommodation. The average monthly rent for a private room in Lisbon is €490. The average monthly rent for a studio in Lisbon is €1,056. The average monthly rent for an apartment in Lisbon is €1,750.

chunks: NOVA IMS is located in Campus de Campolide. Campus de Campolide provides facilities such as school residence, food services, bank machine, health services, and spaces for leisure and physical activities. NOVA IMS provides services such as Academic Services, IT services, and Library and Documentation Services. Academic Services offer support and information regarding enrollment. Academic Services offer support and information regarding timetables and calendars. Academic Services offer support and information regarding exams schedules. Academic Services offer support and information regarding the academic calendar. Helpdesk support is provided by the IT Department to all NOVA IMS enrolled students. The IT Department offers a software set from ESRI, Clarck Labs, Microsoft, MicroStrategy, OutSystems, QlikView, SAP, SAS, and SYBASE for teaching and research purposes. NOVA IMS Library specializes in the areas of Statistics and Information Management. NOVA IMS Library aims to provide students, teachers, and researchers access to documentation and information necessary for scientific and academic activities. NOVA IMS Library provides access to approximately 5,000 books, theses, and dissertations in paper and electronic versions. NOVA IMS Library provides access to electronic journals from JSTOR, Emerald, Wiley Blackwell, and B-On Online Knowledge Library. B-On Online Knowledge Library includes over 22,000 scientific international publications from 19 publishers. Following students' admission to NOVA IMS, the Admissions Office shares the list of admitted students with the Directorate General for Higher Education. NOVA IMS admission does not include dormitory accommodations. NOVA University of Lisbon has 3 Residence Halls to accommodate students, teachers, and researchers from the 9 existing Faculties. Priority for NOVA University residences is given to Portuguese scholarship holders and foreign students on mobility programs.

It is the student's responsibility to ensure they fulfill the necessary requirements to be eligible for a student visa. Nationals from EU/EFTA nations do not need a visa to study in Portugal. Starting in 2026, ETIAS travel authorization will be an entry requirement for non-EU visa-free nationals. EU/EFTA students staying in Portugal for longer than 3 months must apply for the Certificado do Registo de Cidadão da União Europeia (CRUE Certificate of Residency). The CRUE Certificate of Residency must be applied for at the local Council within 30 days following the first three months in Portugal. Students holding a residence permit issued by a Member State of the European Union are authorized to enter and stay in Portugal for a maximum of 90 days within any 180-day period. EU students extending their stay beyond 90 days need to apply for a residence permit for higher education students with visa exemption under no. 4 of article 91 of REPSAE. Students from non-EU nations usually need a visa to study in Portugal. Non-EU students must contact the embassy or consulate of Portugal in their home country to determine if they need a visa and how to apply. Visa application processing times can vary greatly depending on application volumes and the applicant’s home country. It is recommended to submit the complete visa application at least two months prior to the student’s departure. Documents required for a student visa application to Portugal include: a National Visa application filled and duly signed by the applicant. Documents required for a student visa application to Portugal include: two passport-type photos in good condition. Documents required for a student visa application to Portugal include: a passport or other valid travel document valid for 3 months after the estimated date of return and a photocopy of passport biographical data. Documents required for a student visa application to Portugal include: proof of regular status if you are of a nationality other than the country where you are applying. Documents required for a student visa application to Portugal include: valid travel insurance covering medical expenses, urgent medical assistance, and repatriation. Documents required for a student visa application to Portugal include: a criminal record certificate issued by the competent authority of the applicant’s nationality or residence (with Hague Apostille or legalized). Documents required for a student visa application to Portugal include: proof of financial resources/means of subsistence as defined by government decree. Documents required for a student visa application to Portugal include: a document certifying enrollment or fulfillment of admission criteria issued by the higher education institution. Documents required for a student visa application to Portugal include: proof of housing. Consular posts may request additional documents, including authenticated academic documentation, when processing a visa application. Portuguese visa processing times can take anywhere from two weeks to two months depending on the visit purpose. It is advisable to start the Portuguese visa application process as soon as the Admission Letter is received. It is not recommended to enter Portugal with a Tourist Visa (Schengen Visa) if planning to stay for over 3 months. Portuguese Agency for Integration, Migration, and Asylum (AIMA) has delays in scheduling appointments for residence permits. The Directorate General for Higher Education transmits the list of admitted students to the Directorate General of Consular Affairs and Portuguese Communities. NOVA IMS' International Student Support Office provides visa information and offers assistance in applying for a student visa. NOVA IMS cannot influence Embassy decisions regarding visas. Visa processes are managed by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, not NOVA IMS. It is recommended to apply for a visa as soon as possible to account for time and attention required. It is recommended to verify documentation requirements with Embassies and Consulates when applying for a visa. Submitting forms with mistakes can result in visa request refusal. EU/EFTA students who remain in Portugal for longer than 3 months must apply for the Certificado do Registo de Cidadão da União Europeia (CRUE Certificate of Residency). Third-country nationals with a Temporary Stay Visa for Study staying longer than 365 days can request an extension from AIMA within 30 days of its expiration. Third-country nationals with a residence permit in Portugal issued within the EU for higher education students planning to stay longer than 90 days must apply for a Residence Permit under article 91, REPSAE. Third-country nationals with a Residence Visa for Higher Education in Portugal planning to stay longer than 90 days must apply for a Residence Permit for higher education students. Pre-scheduled appointments can be noted on visa stamps if applying for residence permits. Specific forms signed by the applicant are needed to apply for a Residence Permit. Residence Permit applications must be delivered in person at an AIMA location by appointment. Third-country nationals require a valid passport to apply for a residence permit. Third-country nationals require proof of means of subsistence to apply for a residence permit. Third-country nationals need to present criminal records from their nationality or residence country for residence permits. Foreign citizens can authorize AIMA to access their record for residence permits. Third-country nationals are allowed to work in Portugal if they hold a residence permit for higher education students. Higher education students holding residence permits in EU Member States with mobility measures can work in Portugal. Temporary stay visa holders in Portugal are not authorized to work.
It is advised to keep copies of documents submitted for visa applications.

Most students have to find housing through the private market due to limited places in residence halls. NOVA University created Rede ¼ to connect room providers with students needing housing in greater Lisbon.
Rede ¼ has a wide network of partners and a multidisciplinary team.

The National Health Service (SNS) guarantees healthcare access to all residents in Portugal. EU/EFTA nationals benefit from free or reduced-cost healthcare via the European Health Insurance Card (EHIC). Third-country nationals must have medical insurance for their stay in Portugal. Third-country nationals in Portugal beyond 90 days can apply for an SNS card for access to healthcare services. A Social Security Identification Number (NISS) is required to access labor benefits in Portugal.

Opening a bank account in Portugal is recommended for third-country nationals due to foreign withdrawal fees. Applicants need their passport and Portuguese fiscal number to open a bank account. A temporary NIF number might be provided during student visa processing.

Portuguese Language courses are available at NOVA University’s Faculty of Social Sciences and Humanities (FCSH). Portuguese Host Language Programme (PLA) is available through public education institutions and Qualifica Centres.
NOVA IMS Social Mobility Scholarship is available to students in financial need.
Lisbon’s public transport system consists of metro, trams, buses, funiculars, commuter trains, and ferries. Students up to 23 years old benefit from a 100% discount on the Navegante transport pass.

chunks: The Social Security Identification Number (NISS) allows unique, precise, and accurate identification of citizens in the Social Security system at the national level. The Social Security Identification Number (NISS) is automatically allocated to national citizens when they apply for the Citizen Card. Foreign citizens and national citizens who are not required to have a Citizen Card must submit a request for a Social Security Identification Number (NISS). The request for a Social Security Identification Number (NISS) for these citizens is submitted via an online form called Pedido de NISS – Cidadão Estrangeiro ou Cidadão Nacional sem obrigatoriedade de ter cartão de cidadão. The Social Security Identification Number (NISS) for legal persons is automatically allocated when companies are created online. Legal persons registered at commercial registry offices trigger electronic and free-of-charge communication to the Social Security Institute. Legal persons' registration is mandatory and communicated to Social Security by the Tax and Customs Authority (AT). Legal persons' registration is communicated to Social Security during activity beginning communication. Legal persons' registration is communicated to Social Security during the creation of companies or associations under certain schemes. Legal persons' registration is communicated to Social Security during the admission of the first worker for natural persons employing others under employment contracts. Legal persons' registration is communicated to Social Security during inspection activities when entities with workers are created without official registration. Information on NISS allocation for legal persons is available in the Practical Guide – Registration and Change of Data – Legal Person. National citizens with a Citizen Card automatically receive a Social Security Identification Number (NISS). Foreign citizens and national citizens not required to have a Citizen Card must request a Social Security Identification Number (NISS) through the online form available on the Social Security Portal. Employers submitting applications for NISS allocation are exclusively doing so for foreign workers. The Employer must communicate the worker's employment relationship through the Social Security Online Service (SSD – Segurança Social Direta). Applicants themselves must submit necessary documents for NISS applications. National citizens without a Citizen Card must submit a valid ID card for the NISS application. Foreign citizens from non-EU/EEA countries must submit copies of a Passport or Residence Permit (Temporary/Permanent) for the NISS application. Foreign citizens from EU/EEA countries or Switzerland must submit copies of a civil identification document, Passport, or Residence Card for the NISS application. Citizens under International Protection must submit relevant proof of status for NISS applications. The residence permit replaces the ID document for foreign citizens as per Article 84 of Law no. 23/2007. Documentary evidence required for NISS allocation includes employment contracts for employees or domestic service workers. Documentary evidence required for NISS allocation includes proof of self-employment activity and receipts/invoices for self-employed persons. Documentary evidence required for NISS allocation includes company registration certificates for Members of Statutory Bodies. Documentary evidence required for NISS allocation includes proof of an employment contract with a foreign Employer for Digital Nomads. Documentary evidence required for NISS allocation includes proof of eligibility for Voluntary Social Insurance Scheme. Foreign citizens from third countries must attach proof of residence permits or relevant visas to the NISS application form. Members of Statutory Bodies residing outside Portugal must submit an ID document and proof of membership instead of residence permits. Foreign citizens from EU/EEA countries or Switzerland can attach residential register numbers or residence cards to the NISS application form. Employers or legal representatives submitting NISS applications must submit proof of their ID and formal proof of legal representation. Employers or legal representatives submitting NISS applications may also submit Form PA-12 and an ID document instead of a power of attorney. Applicants must provide all identification data, including name, date of birth, gender, marital status, country of birth, place of birth, nationality, type and number of civil ID document, and more. Foreign citizens fulfilling certain conditions may request NISS, NIF, and NNU allocation in a single application. Necessary conditions for the allocation of NISS, NIF, and NNU include holding or applying for a residence permit. Necessary conditions for the allocation of NISS, NIF, and NNU include being nationals of an EU country. Necessary conditions for the allocation of NISS, NIF, and NNU include applying for International Protection or having refugee status. The application for NISS, NIF, and NNU numbers can be submitted at specific Citizen Spaces in Portugal. Citizens submitting NISS, NIF, and NNU allocation requests must authenticate with Digital Mobile Key (CMD) or eIDAS. Foreign nationals submitting multiple NISS requests will receive only one NISS. Exceptional situations exist where foreign citizens cannot submit certain documents for NISS applications. AIMA, I.P. may request NISS allocation for foreign citizens to grant them residence permits for professional activities. Foreign citizens in exceptional situations, such as those with job search visas, must attach a statement from AIMA, I.P. to the NISS application form. EU regulations require attaching documents necessary for Social Security benefits to the NISS application form, regardless of nationality. The NISS document is collected by the person to whom it is allocated upon presenting a valid ID document. The NISS document may be collected by a Lawyer with a professional certificate and power of attorney. A third party can collect the NISS document with an original power of attorney or Form PA-12 and the relevant ID document. The notification of NISS allocation is sent to the applicant's address or legal representative by Registered Letter. Appointments to collect NISS documents can be scheduled through the Appointments Line on business days. Additional details on NISS for foreign citizens and national citizens without Citizen Cards are available in the Practical Guide.

Relevant visas for foreign citizens include residence visas for subordinate professional activity, self-employed persons, teaching, research, cultural activities, remote work, and other purposes. A frontier worker must submit proof of employment or self-employment instead of a residence permit.

chunks_for_embedding.content: The Social Security Identification Number (NISS) allows unique, precise, and accurate identification of citizens in the Social Security system at the national level. The Social Security Identification Number (NISS) for legal persons is automatically allocated when companies are created online. Legal persons registered at commercial registry offices trigger electronic and free-of-charge communication to the Social Security Institute. Legal persons' registration is mandatory and communicated to Social Security by the Tax and Customs Authority (AT). Legal persons' registration is communicated to Social Security during activity beginning communication. Legal persons' registration is communicated to Social Security during the creation of companies or associations under certain schemes. Legal persons' registration is communicated to Social Security during the admission of the first worker for natural persons employing others under employment contracts. Legal persons' registration is communicated to Social Security during inspection activities when entities with workers are created without official registration. Information on NISS allocation for legal persons is available in the Practical Guide – Registration and Change of Data – Legal Person. Foreign citizens and national citizens not required to have a Citizen Card must request a Social Security Identification Number (NISS) through the online form available on the Social Security Portal. Employers submitting applications for NISS allocation are exclusively doing so for foreign workers. The Employer must communicate the worker's employment relationship through the Social Security Online Service (SSD – Segurança Social Direta). Applicants themselves must submit necessary documents for NISS applications. National citizens without a Citizen Card must submit a valid ID card for the NISS application. Foreign citizens from non-EU/EEA countries must submit copies of a Passport or Residence Permit (Temporary/Permanent) for the NISS application. Foreign citizens from EU/EEA countries or Switzerland must submit copies of a civil identification document, Passport, or Residence Card for the NISS application. Citizens under International Protection must submit relevant proof of status for NISS applications. The residence permit replaces the ID document for foreign citizens as per Article 84 of Law no. 23/2007. Documentary evidence required for NISS allocation includes employment contracts for employees or domestic service workers. Documentary evidence required for NISS allocation includes proof of self-employment activity and receipts/invoices for self-employed persons. Documentary evidence required for NISS allocation includes company registration certificates for Members of Statutory Bodies. Documentary evidence required for NISS allocation includes proof of an employment contract with a foreign Employer for Digital Nomads. Documentary evidence required for NISS allocation includes proof of eligibility for Voluntary Social Insurance Scheme. Foreign citizens from third countries must attach proof of residence permits or relevant visas to the NISS application form. Members of Statutory Bodies residing outside Portugal must submit an ID document and proof of membership instead of residence permits. Foreign citizens from EU/EEA countries or Switzerland can attach residential register numbers or residence cards to the NISS application form. Employers or legal representatives submitting NISS applications must submit proof of their ID and formal proof of legal representation. Employers or legal representatives submitting NISS applications may also submit Form PA-12 and an ID document instead of a power of attorney. Applicants must provide all identification data, including name, date of birth, gender, marital status, country of birth, place of birth, nationality, type and number of civil ID document, and more. Foreign citizens fulfilling certain conditions may request NISS, NIF, and NNU allocation in a single application. Necessary conditions for the allocation of NISS, NIF, and NNU include holding or applying for a residence permit. Necessary conditions for the allocation of NISS, NIF, and NNU include being nationals of an EU country. Necessary conditions for the allocation of NISS, NIF, and NNU include applying for International Protection or having refugee status. The application for NISS, NIF, and NNU numbers can be submitted at specific Citizen Spaces in Portugal. Citizens submitting NISS, NIF, and NNU allocation requests must authenticate with Digital Mobile Key (CMD) or eIDAS. Foreign nationals submitting multiple NISS requests will receive only one NISS. Exceptional situations exist where foreign citizens cannot submit certain documents for NISS applications. AIMA, I.P. may request NISS allocation for foreign citizens to grant them residence permits for professional activities. Foreign citizens in exceptional situations, such as those with job search visas, must attach a statement from AIMA, I.P. to the NISS application form. EU regulations require attaching documents necessary for Social Security benefits to the NISS application form, regardless of nationality. The NISS document is collected by the person to whom it is allocated upon presenting a valid ID document. The NISS document may be collected by a Lawyer with a professional certificate and power of attorney. A third party can collect the NISS document with an original power of attorney or Form PA-12 and the relevant ID document. The notification of NISS allocation is sent to the applicant's address or legal representative by Registered Letter. Appointments to collect NISS documents can be scheduled through the Appointments Line on business days. Additional details on NISS for foreign citizens and national citizens without Citizen Cards are available in the Practical Guide.

chunks: Frequently asked questions can be explored to find answers.
If you have unanswered questions, you can contact NOVA IMS.

It is only possible to submit applications during the applications phase. The date of the call for applications is available on the Admissions and Fees page of each program. You can fill the application form at any time and submit it when the applications phase starts. Applications are submitted online in NOVA IMS’ Applications Portal. To submit an application, applicants must register in NOVA IMS’ Applications Portal. Applicants must fill the form in the Applications Portal. Applicants must upload their Curriculum Vitae in the Applications Portal. Applicants must choose the program in the Applications Portal. Applicants must pay the application fee in the Applications Portal. The application process is the same for all applicants, national or international. During the application process, the only mandatory document is the Curriculum Vitae (in .doc or .pdf format). Applicants can upload other documents such as diplomas or certificates of their qualifications. The application fee for the academic year 2025-26 is €51. The application fee is paid during the application process in NOVA IMS’ Applications Portal. Payment methods for the application fee include bank transfer or ATM reference, MBWay, PayPal, or Visa. Applications are considered successfully submitted only after the payment of the application fee within the stipulated time. The application fee is non-refundable in case of withdrawal or non-admission to a program. Applicants can apply to a maximum of 2 programs per application phase. To apply to multiple programs, applicants must pay an application fee for each program. Applying to 1 program equals the payment of 1 application fee. Applying to 2 programs equals the payment of 2 application fees. Final-year bachelor's degree students graduating by September 2025 are eligible to apply. Final-year bachelor's degree students must deliver an authenticated copy of their degree certificate or diploma by the beginning of the academic year in September 2025. In the application form field requesting 'Goals/motivation to apply to this program,' applicants should mention how their academic and professional background fits the program. Applicants should state their short-term professional goals in the field for 'Goals/motivation to apply to this program.' Applicants should specify their expectations from attending the program in the application form field 'Goals/motivation to apply to this program.' The selection process is based on the analysis of the academic and professional curriculum. The Admissions Jury Panel may decide to hold interviews with all or some candidates. Interviews may be face-to-face or conducted via videoconference. Interviews can be held at a distance using Zoom. Application results are announced via email on a date specified in the confirmation of submitted application email or by the Admissions Jury or Programs Manager. Admitted applicants must pay the pre-registration fee approximately one week after the results are announced. Admitted applicants must upload the diploma or certificate of their latest qualification after paying the pre-registration fee. Examples of latest qualifications required for admitted applicants include Bachelor’s degree, Master’s degree, or PhD. Applicants may attend two programs per academic year. Attending two programs per academic year is not recommended due to possible overlaps in Mandatory Course Units and exams. Admitted candidates to two programs must choose one program in the Applications Portal. Admitted candidates must pay the pre-registration fee for the chosen program. Candidates admitted to two programs must select the 'Withdrawal' option for the program they do not intend to attend. By withdrawing from the second program, the vacancy becomes available to Waiting List candidates. Candidates on the Waiting List may still be admitted. If a candidate admitted to two programs chooses to attend only one and there are remaining vacancies, Waiting List candidates may be assigned these vacancies. Invoices for application or pre-registration fees are available in NOVA IMS’ Applications Portal. NOVA IMS can issue a document proving program admission for visa purposes. The document proving program admission is sent to the student and the Embassy. The admission document is issued only after payment of the pre-registration fee. Students must contact the Portuguese Embassy or Consulate in their country for further information regarding visas.

Several websites can be used to convert files to PDF format. The websites for converting files to PDF format include: https://smallpdf.com/word-to-pdf, https://www.zamzar.com/, https://cloudconvert.com/, https://www.ilovepdf.com/, https://online2pdf.com/doc-to-pdf.

The Tax Identification Number in Portugal is required to identify a taxable entity or person for tax declarations or financial transactions. Applicants who do not have a Tax Identification Number should enter “999999999” in the application form field requesting it. The Invoice-Receipt is available within 2 business days after payment in the 'Billing/Treasury' tab of the Applications Portal.

NOVA IMS does not award scholarships. Applicants can apply for Universidade Nova de Lisboa scholarships and financial support provided by the university’s Social Welfare Services. Information about scholarships is available at https://sas.unl.pt/en/scholarships-2/scholarships_/. Applicants can contact bolsas@unl.pt for information about Universidade Nova de Lisboa scholarships. NOVA IMS does not hold information about other scholarships.

Students can park vehicles on campus if they have an access card. Several parking areas are available on campus and near NOVA IMS. Requests for vehicle access to Campus de Campolide require registration or renewal of registration and payment. Registration for vehicle access is completed in the system by selecting the type of access. Parking space management is the exclusive responsibility of the NOVA Rectory. Information about Campus de Campolide parking is available at http://www.unl.pt/en/nova/parking-campus.

The Social Welfare Services of Universidade Nova have ties with three student residences. One of the student residences is located in Campus de Campolide. Student residences provide accommodation for Portuguese scholarship students and international students. The capacity of student residences is limited. NOVA IMS cannot guarantee a room in the student residences. Applicants can be placed on the waiting list for residences only after confirmation of admission. Information about student residences is available at https://sas.unl.pt/en/accommodation/. Admitted students seeking accommodation in university residences should contact adnovaims@novaims.unl.pt. NOVA IMS provides a list of reference websites for accommodation. Accommodation websites in the reference list include: Airbnb, BQuarto, Casa Alfacinha, Collegiate, Coolivin, Easy Roommate, Erasmusu, Erasmus Life Lisboa, Erasmus Lisboa, Erasmus Student Network, Fundação Cidade de Lisboa, Housing Anywhere, Houze Student, Lemon Garden, Lisbon Rooms, Livensa Living, Residência Avenidas, Accommodation at Rua Fialho de Almeida 17 4E, Spot A Home, The Housing Concept, Traveling To Lisbon, UHub, Uniplaces, and Wimdu.

The university offers a Portuguese course for international students. The Portuguese course is available in four types of classes: individual lessons, semester group lessons, 30-hour intensive course, and online summer course. Individual lessons are scheduled based on the student's availability and arranged with the teacher. The 30-hour intensive course is conducted over two weeks. Questions about the Portuguese course can be directed to cursoportugues@fcsh.unl.pt.
The semester group lessons include 56 study classes and 8 hours for other activities.
The online summer course takes place in July.

chunks_for_embedding.title: Academic Application Procedures and Admission
chunks_for_embedding.summary: This chunk outlines the comprehensive academic application process, including phases, documentation guidelines, fee payments, program choices, interviews, result announcements, pre-registration steps, policies for multiple applications, withdrawal options, fee invoicing, and visa support for admitted students.
chunks_for_embedding.content: It is only possible to submit applications during the applications phase. The date of the call for applications is available on the Admissions and Fees page of each program. You can fill the application form at any time and submit it when the applications phase starts. Applications are submitted online in NOVA IMS’ Applications Portal. To submit an application, applicants must register in NOVA IMS’ Applications Portal. Applicants must fill the form in the Applications Portal. Applicants must upload their Curriculum Vitae in the Applications Portal. Applicants must choose the program in the Applications Portal. Applicants must pay the application fee in the Applications Portal. The application process is the same for all applicants, national or international. During the application process, the only mandatory document is the Curriculum Vitae (in .doc or .pdf format). Applicants can upload other documents such as diplomas or certificates of their qualifications. The application fee for the academic year 2025-26 is €51. The application fee is paid during the application process in NOVA IMS’ Applications Portal. Payment methods for the application fee include bank transfer or ATM reference, MBWay, PayPal, or Visa. Applications are considered successfully submitted only after the payment of the application fee within the stipulated time. The application fee is non-refundable in case of withdrawal or non-admission to a program. Applicants can apply to a maximum of 2 programs per application phase. To apply to multiple programs, applicants must pay an application fee for each program. Applying to 1 program equals the payment of 1 application fee. Applying to 2 programs equals the payment of 2 application fees. Final-year bachelor's degree students graduating by September 2025 are eligible to apply. Final-year bachelor's degree students must deliver an authenticated copy of their degree certificate or diploma by the beginning of the academic year in September 2025. In the application form field requesting 'Goals/motivation to apply to this program,' applicants should mention how their academic and professional background fits the program. Applicants should state their short-term professional goals in the field for 'Goals/motivation to apply to this program.' Applicants should specify their expectations from attending the program in the application form field 'Goals/motivation to apply to this program.' The selection process is based on the analysis of the academic and professional curriculum. The Admissions Jury Panel may decide to hold interviews with all or some candidates. Interviews may be face-to-face or conducted via videoconference. Interviews can be held at a distance using Zoom. Application results are announced via email on a date specified in the confirmation of submitted application email or by the Admissions Jury or Programs Manager. Admitted applicants must pay the pre-registration fee approximately one week after the results are announced. Admitted applicants must upload the diploma or certificate of their latest qualification after paying the pre-registration fee. Examples of latest qualifications required for admitted applicants include Bachelor’s degree, Master’s degree, or PhD. Applicants may attend two programs per academic year. Attending two programs per academic year is not recommended due to possible overlaps in Mandatory Course Units and exams. Admitted candidates to two programs must choose one program in the Applications Portal. Admitted candidates must pay the pre-registration fee for the chosen program. Candidates admitted to two programs must select the 'Withdrawal' option for the program they do not intend to attend. By withdrawing from the second program, the vacancy becomes available to Waiting List candidates. Candidates on the Waiting List may still be admitted. If a candidate admitted to two programs chooses to attend only one and there are remaining vacancies, Waiting List candidates may be assigned these vacancies. Invoices for application or pre-registration fees are available in NOVA IMS’ Applications Portal. NOVA IMS can issue a document proving program admission for visa purposes. The document proving program admission is sent to the student and the Embassy. The admission document is issued only after payment of the pre-registration fee. Students must contact the Portuguese Embassy or Consulate in their country for further information regarding visas.

chunks_for_embedding.title: Tax & Financial Processes
chunks_for_embedding.summary: This chunk contains information about tax identification requirements in Portugal, their purposes, instructions for applicants without a Tax Identification Number, and details about invoice-receipt availability.
chunks_for_embedding.content: The Tax Identification Number in Portugal is required to identify a taxable entity or person for tax declarations or financial transactions. Applicants who do not have a Tax Identification Number should enter “999999999” in the application form field requesting it. The Invoice-Receipt is available within 2 business days after payment in the 'Billing/Treasury' tab of the Applications Portal.

chunks: Law no. 23/2007, of July 4, approves the legal regime for the entry, stay, exit, and removal of foreigners from Portuguese national territory. Article 91 of Law no. 23/2007, in conjunction with Article 57 of Regulatory Decree no. 84/07 of November 5, establishes the framework for issuing residence permits to higher education students. A residence permit is granted to higher education students holding a residence visa issued under Article 62 of REPSAE. Higher education students must meet the general conditions of Article 77 of REPSAE to obtain a residence permit. Higher education students must demonstrate that they meet admission requirements or have been accepted by a higher education institution to obtain a residence permit. Higher education students must possess sufficient resources to attend a study program to obtain a residence permit. A residence permit may be granted to a higher education student who does not hold a residence visa issued under Article 62 of REPSAE. Higher education students without a residence visa must have entered Portuguese national territory legally to obtain a residence permit. Higher education students without a residence visa must meet the conditions established in Article 91 of REPSAE to obtain a residence permit. The application for a residence permit must be submitted by appointment or via an electronic platform in an implementation phase for residence visa holders. The application for a residence permit must be presented in person and accompanied by a specific form signed by the applicant or their legal representative. The application for a residence permit can be submitted at any AIMA Service Center. AIMA Service Centers may forward residence permit applications, after processing and decision, to services in the applicant’s area of residence. The application for a residence permit must include two identical passport-style color photographs with a plain, updated background suitable for identification. Photographs are required only if applying at AIMA Service Centers in Odivelas or Aveiro. The application for a residence permit must include a valid passport or other travel document. The application for a residence permit must include a valid residence visa issued under Article 62 of REPSAE, except in cases of applications without a visa under paragraph 4 of Article 91 of REPSAE. The application for a residence permit must include a declaration under oath of residence address specifying the terms of residence. Applicants residing as owners or usufructuaries must include a land registry certificate or access code to verify property or usufruct rights. Applicants residing as tenants or licensees must include a declaration from the landlord or hosting entity stating the legal basis for property use. The application for a residence permit must include proof of means of subsistence as required by Ordinance no. 1563/2007, of December 11. The application for a residence permit must include a criminal record certificate from the applicant’s country of nationality. Applicants must provide a criminal record certificate from the country where they resided for more than one year before moving to Portugal. Applicants must authenticate criminal record certificates as required by regulation. Applicants applying for a residence permit without a visa, under paragraph 4 of Article 91 of Law no. 23/2007, must provide proof of legal entry into Portuguese national territory. The application for a residence permit must include proof of enrollment at a higher education institution. The application for a residence permit must include proof of tuition fee payments required by the higher education institution, certified by a declaration if applicable. The application for a residence permit must include health insurance or proof of coverage by the National Health Service. Higher education students admitted under paragraph 5 of Article 91 of REPSAE are exempt from submitting proof of means of subsistence. Higher education students admitted under paragraph 5 of Article 91 of REPSAE are exempt from submitting proof of tuition payment. Higher education students receiving a scholarship from Instituto Camões are exempt from providing proof of enrollment. Higher education students receiving a scholarship from Instituto Camões are exempt from providing proof of tuition payment. Higher education students receiving a scholarship from Instituto Camões are exempt from providing proof of health insurance. Higher education students receiving a scholarship from Instituto Camões are exempt from providing proof of means of subsistence. Granting a residence permit requires the absence of facts that would have prevented visa issuance if known to the authorities. Granting a residence permit requires the absence of convictions for crimes punishable in Portugal by imprisonment for more than one year. Granting a residence permit requires the applicant not be subject to a ban on entry or stay in Portuguese national territory following a removal order. Granting a residence permit requires no alert in the Schengen Information System (SIS). Granting a residence permit requires no alert in the Foreigners’ Central Information Unit System (SII UCFE) for refusal of entry, stay, or re-entry under Articles 33 and 33-A. The residence permit granted under Article 91 of REPSAE to higher education students is valid for three years. The residence permit granted under Article 91 of REPSAE to higher education students is renewable for equal periods. If the study program duration is shorter than three years, the residence permit is issued for the duration of the program. The residence permit granted to students in EU or multilateral programs involving mobility measures is valid for two years or for the program duration, if shorter. The residence permit granted to students under agreements between two or more higher education institutions is valid for two years or for the program duration, if shorter. The residence permit may be valid for one year if the conditions under paragraph 4 of Article 62 of REPSAE are not met at issuance. Residence permit holders for study purposes may work in addition to the activity that justified their visa, as stipulated in Article 97 of REPSAE. Directive (EU) 2016/801 of the European Parliament and Council of May 11, 2016, regulates entry and residence conditions for third-country nationals for research, studies, training, voluntary service, student exchange programs, educational projects, and au pair placements.

The application for a residence permit must include health insurance or proof of coverage by the National Health Service.
Higher education students admitted under paragraph 5 of Article 91 of REPSAE are exempt from submitting proof of means of subsistence.
Higher education students admitted under paragraph 5 of Article 91 of REPSAE are exempt from submitting proof of tuition payment.
Higher education students receiving a scholarship from Instituto Camões are exempt from providing proof of enrollment.
Higher education students receiving a scholarship from Instituto Camões are exempt from providing proof of tuition payment.
Higher education students receiving a scholarship from Instituto Camões are exempt from providing proof of health insurance.
Higher education students receiving a scholarship from Instituto Camões are exempt from providing proof of means of subsistence.
Granting a residence permit requires the absence of facts that would have prevented visa issuance if known to the authorities.
Granting a residence permit requires the absence of convictions for crimes punishable in Portugal by imprisonment for more than one year.
Granting a residence permit requires the applicant not be subject to a ban on entry or stay in Portuguese national territory following a removal order.
Granting a residence permit requires no alert in the Schengen Information System (SIS).
Granting a residence permit requires no alert in the Foreigners’ Central Information Unit System (SII UCFE) for refusal of entry, stay, or re-entry under Articles 33 and 33-A.
The residence permit granted under Article 91 of REPSAE to higher education students is valid for three years.
The residence permit granted under Article 91 of REPSAE to higher education students is renewable for equal periods.
If the study program duration is shorter than three years, the residence permit is issued for the duration of the program.
The residence permit granted to students in EU or multilateral programs involving mobility measures is valid for two years or for the program duration, if shorter.
The residence permit granted to students under agreements between two or more higher education institutions is valid for two years or for the program duration, if shorter.
The residence permit may be valid for one year if the conditions under paragraph 4 of Article 62 of REPSAE are not met at issuance.
Residence permit holders for study purposes may work in addition to the activity that justified their visa, as stipulated in Article 97 of REPSAE.

Directive (EU) 2016/801 of the European Parliament and Council of May 11, 2016, regulates entry and residence conditions for third-country nationals for research, studies, training, voluntary service, student exchange programs, educational projects, and au pair placements.

chunks: Ordinance no. 1563/2007, of December 11, establishes the means of subsistence that third-country nationals must have for entry and stay in Portugal. The reference value for the means of subsistence is the guaranteed monthly minimum wage, that is, the national minimum wage. According to Decree-Law no. 107/2023, of November 17, the minimum wage set for 2024 is €820. Article 273 of the Labor Code specifies the national minimum wage set for 2024 as €820. To apply for family reunification, the applicant's household must have 100% of the minimum wage for the first adult. To apply for family reunification, the applicant's household must have 50% of the minimum wage for the second or more adults. To apply for family reunification, the applicant's household must have 30% of the minimum wage for children under 18 years old. To apply for family reunification, the applicant's household must have 30% of the minimum wage for dependent adult children. For the purposes of family reunification, the required amount of means of subsistence is calculated based on the specified percentages. Proof of financial means depends on the applicant's situation. Proof of financial means may include a copy of a promise of employment contract or an employment contract. Proof of financial means may include pay slips for the last three months. Proof of financial means may include a copy of a service provision contract or a promise of service provision contract. Proof of financial means may include a declaration of business activity initiation. Proof of financial means may include receipts for the past six months of services rendered. Proof of financial means for remote work carried out for an entity outside the national territory may include a copy of the employment contract. Proof of financial means for remote work carried out for an entity outside the national territory may include a declaration from the employer. Proof of financial means for freelance work carried out remotely for entities outside the national territory may include a copy of the company’s articles of association. Proof of financial means for freelance work carried out remotely for entities outside the national territory may include a service provision contract. Proof of financial means for freelance work carried out remotely for entities outside the national territory may include a document proving services provided to one or more entities. Proof of financial means may include a declaration issued by a competent authority confirming an employment relationship. Proof of financial means may include a declaration issued by a competent authority confirming service provision. Proof of financial means may include a declaration issued by a competent authority confirming the award of a scientific research grant. Proof of financial means may include a declaration issued by a competent authority confirming the signing of a hosting agreement. Proof of financial means may include a declaration issued by an educational institution. Proof of financial means may include a declaration issued by a training provider. Proof of financial means may include a declaration issued by a volunteer program organizer. Proof of financial means for retirees or pensioners may include a certificate issued by the official entity of the country granting the pension. Proof of financial means for retirees or pensioners may include an authenticated declaration. Proof of financial means for income from financial investments may include a document issued by the paying entity of the income generated by the investment. Proof of financial means for income from financial investments may include an authenticated declaration. Proof of financial means may include a business incorporation contract for proof of entrepreneurial activity. Proof of financial means may include a declaration issued by IAPMEI confirming the existence of a business incubation agreement. Proof of financial means may include proof of available financial resources in Portugal. Proof of financial means may include proof of financial resources held in a Portuguese financial institution. Proof of financial means may include a statement of intent to make an investment operation in Portugal.

chunks: A National Visa application must be filled and duly signed by the applicant. For minors and incapacitated individuals, forms must be signed by the legal guardian. Two passport-type photos are required, even, recent, and in good condition to identify the applicant. One photo is specifically required for the form. A passport or other travel document must be valid for three months after the estimated date of return. A photocopy of the passport's biographical data page is required. Proof of regular status must be provided if the applicant is of a nationality other than the country where they are applying for a visa. Proof of regular status must be valid for more than the expiration date of the visa being applied for. A criminal record certificate must be issued by the competent authority of the applicant's nationality or the country where the applicant has resided for over a year. A criminal record certificate is not required for applicants under the age of sixteen. A criminal record certificate must have the Hague Apostille or be legalized if applicable. Proof of financial resources must be provided as defined by decree of competent government members. For proof of means of subsistence, funds from contracts, promises of employment contracts, grants, or scholarships may be considered. Applicants for residence visas who are third-country nationals from Portuguese-speaking countries are exempt from providing proof of means of subsistence.

Valid travel insurance must cover necessary medical expenses, including urgent medical assistance and possible repatriation. The requirement for travel insurance may be waived under Bilateral or International Agreements between Portugal and the applicant's country of origin concerning medical assistance. Applicants with recognized insurance such as PB4 from Brazil or S1 from the United Kingdom may qualify for an exemption from the travel insurance requirement.

When minors are not traveling with both parents, a travel authorization from one or both parents or a court order is required. When minors are traveling with a third person, a travel authorization from one or both parents or a court order is required. A copy of the parent's identity card must be provided for minors traveling without both parents.

For research purposes, a work contract or host agreement with the research center or university must be provided. For research purposes, a letter of acceptance by the research center or university and proof of scholarship or research grant must be provided. For research purposes, a statement of responsibility signed by the research center or university to cover admission and living costs must be provided. Researchers admitted to a research center or higher education institution officially recognized under Article 91-B of Law 23/2007 are exempt from presenting health insurance or equivalent. Researchers admitted to a research center or higher education institution officially recognized under Article 91-B of Law 23/2007 are exempt from presenting an employment contract or convention. Researchers admitted to a research center or higher education institution officially recognized under Article 91-B of Law 23/2007 are exempt from presenting travel insurance. Researchers admitted to a research center or higher education institution officially recognized under Article 91-B of Law 23/2007 are exempt from presenting proof of means of subsistence. Applicants benefiting from a study or research grant are exempt from presenting the document proving admission. Applicants benefiting from a study or research grant are exempt from presenting proof of sufficient means of subsistence if they inform the Consular Post of this fact.

Higher education students must fulfill admission criteria or be accepted to a university for a study program. Higher education students must have sufficient financial resources to attend the study program. Higher education students admitted to higher education institutions officially recognized under Article 91-B of Law 23/2007 are exempt from presenting health insurance or equivalent. Higher education students admitted to higher education institutions officially recognized under Article 91-B of Law 23/2007 are exempt from proving admission conditions. Higher education students admitted to higher education institutions officially recognized under Article 91-B of Law 23/2007 are exempt from proving how they were accepted into the institution. Higher education students admitted to higher education institutions officially recognized under Article 91-B of Law 23/2007 are exempt from presenting travel insurance. Higher education students admitted to higher education institutions officially recognized under Article 91-B of Law 23/2007 are exempt from presenting proof of means of subsistence. Students benefiting from scholarships are exempt from presenting the document proving admission. Students benefiting from scholarships are exempt from presenting proof of sufficient means of subsistence. Scholarship beneficiaries from Camões – Instituto da Cooperação e da Língua are exempt from presenting the document proving admission. Scholarship beneficiaries from Camões – Instituto da Cooperação e da Língua are exempt from presenting proof of sufficient means of subsistence. Applicants for residence visas who are third-country nationals from Portuguese-speaking countries are exempt from providing proof of means of subsistence when admitted to a higher education institution.

chunks: Students enrolled in the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science learn the most modern artificial intelligence and machine learning techniques to analyze large volumes of data (Big Data). Graduates of the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science will become data scientists. The profession of data scientist is considered the sexiest profession of the 21st century by the Harvard Business Review. The main objective of the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science is to train future professionals capable of understanding, developing, and using models, algorithms, and advanced techniques in data science. The main objective of the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science is to analyze and extract knowledge from Big Data. The Bachelor's Degree in Data Science enables quick integration across varied sectors of activity. Career opportunities for graduates of the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science include working at information technology companies, communication companies, banking, insurance, retail, telecommunications, utilities companies, biomedical companies, pharmaceutical companies, public administration, and industrial companies. Main professional opportunities for graduates of the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science include becoming a Big Data Analyst. Main professional opportunities for graduates of the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science include becoming a Data Engineer. Main professional opportunities for graduates of the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science include becoming a Specialist in Machine Learning. Main professional opportunities for graduates of the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science include becoming a Data Scientist. Main professional opportunities for graduates of the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science include becoming a Specialist in Artificial Intelligence Systems. Main professional opportunities for graduates of the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science include becoming a Specialist in the development of Automatic Learning Algorithms. Main professional opportunities for graduates of the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science include holding technical and managerial positions in Public Administration. The Bachelor's Degree in Data Science aims to strengthen the intermediate step between data collection and decision-making. The Bachelor's Degree in Data Science aims to develop advanced methods of data science and artificial intelligence. The course of study for the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science adopts a primarily technical perspective. The course of study for the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science provides in-depth knowledge of the fundamental methodologies and concepts. The course of study for the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science provides the student with the ability to update specific technical knowledge and keep up with rapid evolution in the sector. Graduates in Data Science are expected to understand the theoretical foundations of statistics, Machine Learning methods, and Artificial Intelligence methods. Graduates in Data Science are expected to identify and understand the most efficient algorithm for each specific problem. Graduates in Data Science are expected to design and develop state-of-the-art data science algorithms. Graduates in Data Science are expected to work closely with IT specialists to integrate Data Science algorithms into existing systems. Graduates in Data Science are expected to identify underlying patterns and extract useful information from large volumes of heterogeneous data in organizations. Graduates in Data Science are expected to be proficient in commonly used statistical procedures, frameworks, machine learning techniques, and systems. Graduates in Data Science are expected to stimulate interest in keeping up with scientific advances in the field of Data Science and Artificial Intelligence. The Bachelor's Degree in Data Science lasts 3 years (6 semesters). Classes for the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science begin in September 2025. The study plan for the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science corresponds to 180 ECTS. 150 ECTS of the study plan for the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science correspond to mandatory curricular units completed in the first 5 semesters. 30 ECTS of the study plan for the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science correspond to optional curricular units chosen by the student in the last semester. The Bachelor's Degree in Data Science is offered by Universidade Nova de Lisboa - Instituto Superior de Estatística e Gestão de Informação. The course code of the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science is L188. Entry exam subjects for the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science for the 2025/26 academic year include Mathematics A and Biology and Geology. Entry exam subjects for the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science for the 2025/26 academic year include Mathematics A and Economy. Entry exam subjects for the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science for the 2025/26 academic year include Mathematics A and Physics and Chemistry. Entry exam subjects for the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science for the 2025/26 academic year include Mathematics A and Geography. Entry exam subjects for the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science for the 2025/26 academic year include Mathematics A and Descriptive Geometry. Entry exam subjects for the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science for the 2025/26 academic year include Mathematics A and Portuguese. There are no prerequisites for the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science. The number of vacancies for the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science is 45. The program coordinator for the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science is Mauro Castelli. The annual tuition fee for the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science for the academic year 2025/26 for students of the National Contest for Access to Higher Education is €697.

The 4th phase of applications under the International Student Statute for the 2025/26 academic year will be open from April 24th to May 28th, 2025. The exams presented are valid for admissions in the 2025/26 academic year through the National Competition for Access to Higher Education. The minimum grade required for applicants to the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science is 100. The minimum grade required for entry exams for the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science is 95. The formula for the Applicants Grade for the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science consists of 50% Secondary School Grade and 50% Entry Exam Subjects. The last entry grade for the general quota for the 2024/25 academic year for the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science in the 1st phase was 17.78. The annual tuition fee for the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science for the academic year 2025/26 for students of the National Contest for Access to Higher Education can be paid in full or in 10 installments. The annual tuition fee for the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science for the academic year 2025/26 for students of the International Student Contest is €7,500. The annual tuition fee for the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science for the academic year 2025/26 for students of the International Student Contest can be paid in full or in 5 installments. Students registering for a school year must pay the full tuition fee set for that school year, even if they cancel registration or withdraw from the course.

chunks_for_embedding.title: Bachelor's Degree in Data Science Overview
chunks_for_embedding.summary: This chunk contains detailed information about the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science, covering its curriculum, objectives, career paths, admission criteria, institution, program structure, and expected competencies for graduates.
chunks_for_embedding.content: Students enrolled in the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science learn the most modern artificial intelligence and machine learning techniques to analyze large volumes of data (Big Data). Graduates of the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science will become data scientists. The profession of data scientist is considered the sexiest profession of the 21st century by the Harvard Business Review. The main objective of the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science is to train future professionals capable of understanding, developing, and using models, algorithms, and advanced techniques in data science. The main objective of the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science is to analyze and extract knowledge from Big Data. The Bachelor's Degree in Data Science enables quick integration across varied sectors of activity. Career opportunities for graduates of the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science include working at information technology companies, communication companies, banking, insurance, retail, telecommunications, utilities companies, biomedical companies, pharmaceutical companies, public administration, and industrial companies. Main professional opportunities for graduates of the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science include becoming a Big Data Analyst. Main professional opportunities for graduates of the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science include becoming a Data Engineer. Main professional opportunities for graduates of the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science include becoming a Specialist in Machine Learning. Main professional opportunities for graduates of the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science include becoming a Data Scientist. Main professional opportunities for graduates of the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science include becoming a Specialist in Artificial Intelligence Systems. Main professional opportunities for graduates of the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science include becoming a Specialist in the development of Automatic Learning Algorithms. Main professional opportunities for graduates of the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science include holding technical and managerial positions in Public Administration. The Bachelor's Degree in Data Science aims to strengthen the intermediate step between data collection and decision-making. The Bachelor's Degree in Data Science aims to develop advanced methods of data science and artificial intelligence. The course of study for the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science adopts a primarily technical perspective. The course of study for the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science provides in-depth knowledge of the fundamental methodologies and concepts. The course of study for the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science provides the student with the ability to update specific technical knowledge and keep up with rapid evolution in the sector. Graduates in Data Science are expected to understand the theoretical foundations of statistics, Machine Learning methods, and Artificial Intelligence methods. Graduates in Data Science are expected to identify and understand the most efficient algorithm for each specific problem. Graduates in Data Science are expected to design and develop state-of-the-art data science algorithms. Graduates in Data Science are expected to work closely with IT specialists to integrate Data Science algorithms into existing systems. Graduates in Data Science are expected to identify underlying patterns and extract useful information from large volumes of heterogeneous data in organizations. Graduates in Data Science are expected to be proficient in commonly used statistical procedures, frameworks, machine learning techniques, and systems. Graduates in Data Science are expected to stimulate interest in keeping up with scientific advances in the field of Data Science and Artificial Intelligence. The Bachelor's Degree in Data Science lasts 3 years (6 semesters). Classes for the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science begin in September 2025. The study plan for the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science corresponds to 180 ECTS. 150 ECTS of the study plan for the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science correspond to mandatory curricular units completed in the first 5 semesters. 30 ECTS of the study plan for the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science correspond to optional curricular units chosen by the student in the last semester. The Bachelor's Degree in Data Science is offered by Universidade Nova de Lisboa - Instituto Superior de Estatística e Gestão de Informação. The course code of the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science is L188. Entry exam subjects for the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science for the 2025/26 academic year include Mathematics A and Biology and Geology. Entry exam subjects for the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science for the 2025/26 academic year include Mathematics A and Economy. Entry exam subjects for the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science for the 2025/26 academic year include Mathematics A and Physics and Chemistry. Entry exam subjects for the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science for the 2025/26 academic year include Mathematics A and Geography. Entry exam subjects for the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science for the 2025/26 academic year include Mathematics A and Descriptive Geometry. Entry exam subjects for the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science for the 2025/26 academic year include Mathematics A and Portuguese. There are no prerequisites for the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science. The number of vacancies for the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science is 45. The program coordinator for the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science is Mauro Castelli. The annual tuition fee for the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science for the academic year 2025/26 for students of the National Contest for Access to Higher Education is €697.

chunks_for_embedding.title: Admissions & Tuition for Data Science Program
chunks_for_embedding.summary: This chunk contains detailed information about application timelines, admission criteria, grading systems, tuition fees (with payment options), and regulations, specific to the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science for both national and international student pathways.
chunks_for_embedding.content: The 4th phase of applications under the International Student Statute for the 2025/26 academic year will be open from April 24th to May 28th, 2025. The exams presented are valid for admissions in the 2025/26 academic year through the National Competition for Access to Higher Education. The minimum grade required for applicants to the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science is 100. The minimum grade required for entry exams for the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science is 95. The formula for the Applicants Grade for the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science consists of 50% Secondary School Grade and 50% Entry Exam Subjects. The last entry grade for the general quota for the 2024/25 academic year for the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science in the 1st phase was 17.78. The annual tuition fee for the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science for the academic year 2025/26 for students of the National Contest for Access to Higher Education can be paid in full or in 10 installments. The annual tuition fee for the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science for the academic year 2025/26 for students of the International Student Contest is €7,500. The annual tuition fee for the Bachelor's Degree in Data Science for the academic year 2025/26 for students of the International Student Contest can be paid in full or in 5 installments. Students registering for a school year must pay the full tuition fee set for that school year, even if they cancel registration or withdraw from the course.

chunks: The Bachelor’s degree in Information Management combines management with data science. The Bachelor’s degree in Information Management prepares students to be managers of the new generation. The managers of the new generation are capable of understanding business and the current challenges of modern management. Managers of the new generation are capable of transforming data into information. The Bachelor’s degree in Information Management allows quick integration in varied sectors of activity. The Bachelor’s degree in Information Management aims to prepare students for new functions in the information society and knowledge. Graduates in Information Management should master techniques and methodologies for data collection. Graduates in Information Management should master tools and processes for the storage, organization, and access to information in a business context. Graduates in Information Management should understand paradigms and technologies used in information management and dissemination. Graduates in Information Management should master methodologies, statistical tools, and computational tools for exploring and analyzing information to reduce uncertainty in decision-making. Graduates in Information Management should develop models for establishing information flow to improve decision support and business management. Graduates in Information Management should identify problems related to information management in organizations. Graduates in Information Management should transform data into useful and relevant information using accessible language for various decision centers. Graduates in Information Management should develop solutions to new problems based on knowledge gained from previous problems. The Bachelor’s degree in Information Management lasts 3 years (6 semesters). The study plan of the Bachelor’s degree in Information Management corresponds to 180 ECTS. 150 ECTS in the Bachelor’s degree in Information Management corresponds to mandatory curricular units. 30 ECTS in the Bachelor’s degree in Information Management corresponds to optional curricular units chosen by students in the last semester.
In today's society, business is increasingly complex.

Companies deal daily with a huge volume of data generated by numerous sources. There is a high demand for professionals with skills in the area of information management. Professionals in information management are able to use modern techniques and analytical tools to support decision-making. Career opportunities include Business Process Analyst. Career opportunities include Business Analyst. Career opportunities include Data Analyst. Career opportunities include Information Manager. Career opportunities include Specialist in Analytical Marketing. Career opportunities include Specialist in Data Science applied to Management. Career opportunities include Specialist in Decision Support Systems. Career opportunities include Technical and Managerial Positions in Public Administration.

The 4th phase of applications under the International Student Statute for the 2025/26 academic year will be open from April 24th to May 28th, 2025. Classes for the Bachelor’s degree in Information Management start in September 2025. Exams listed are valid for admissions to the 2025/26 academic year through the National Competition for Access to Higher Education. The minimum Applicants Grade for admissions to the Bachelor’s degree in Information Management is 100. The minimum Entry Exam Grade for admissions to the Bachelor’s degree in Information Management is 95. The formula for the Applicants Grade in the Bachelor’s degree in Information Management is: Secondary School Grade 50% + Entry Exam Subjects 50%. There are no prerequisites for admissions to the Bachelor’s degree in Information Management. The General Quota Last Entry Grade for the 2024-2025 academic year was 17.36 in the 1st Phase. The General Quota Last Entry Grade for the 2024-2025 academic year was 17.90 in the 2nd Phase. The annual tuition fee for students in the National Contest for Access to Higher Education for the 2025/26 academic year is €697. The €697 tuition fee can be paid in full or in 10 instalments. The annual tuition fee for students in the International Student Contest for the 2025/26 academic year is €7,500. The €7,500 tuition fee can be paid in full or in 5 instalments. Students must pay the full annual tuition fee even if they cancel registration or withdraw from the course.

Sectors of activity include Information Technology Companies, Banking, Insurance, Health, Telecommunications, Logistics/Distribution, Marketing, Market Research, Retail, Consulting, and Public Administration.

The optional curricular units for the Bachelor’s degree in Information Management include a wide range of choices. The establishment code for the Bachelor’s degree in Information Management is 0906 - Universidade Nova de Lisboa - Instituto Superior de Estatística e Gestão de Informação. The course code for the Bachelor’s degree in Information Management is 9155. Entry exam subjects for the Bachelor’s degree in Information Management include Mathematics A and Economics. Entry exam subjects for the Bachelor’s degree in Information Management include Mathematics A and Biology and Geology. Entry exam subjects for the Bachelor’s degree in Information Management include Mathematics A and Physics and Chemistry. Entry exam subjects for the Bachelor’s degree in Information Management include Mathematics and Portuguese. Entry exam subjects for the Bachelor’s degree in Information Management include Mathematics and Geography. Entry exam subjects for the Bachelor’s degree in Information Management include Mathematics and English. The number of vacancies for the Bachelor’s degree in Information Management is 64. The program coordinator for the Bachelor’s degree in Information Management is Frederico Cruz Jesus.
Frederico Cruz Jesus holds the title of Associate Professor. Frederico Cruz Jesus’s contact email is fjesus@novaims.unl.pt.
